column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Put Spurs on Boots
#Text=Spurs can help improve communication between a rider and a mount .
#Text=If you ’ve selected a shiny new pair of spurs , you may be wondering how to attach them to your favorite cowboy boots .
#Text=The process is quite simple and should only take a few minutes .
#Text=Once you understand and assemble your new spurs , you ’ll have them on your boots and be riding in no time .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Setting up the Spur
#Text=Locate the spur ledge on the back of your cowboy boot .
#Text=The spur ledge is the protruding part of the boot heel that creates a small shelf where the spur heel band will rest .
#Text=The spur ledge is a very slight ledge , just large enough so that the heel band does n’t slip down the boot .
#Text=All cowboy style boots should have a spur ledge .
#Text=If you are not sure about your boots , take them with you when you go to purchase your spurs .
#Text=Find the heel band portion of the spur .
#Text=The heel band is the U-shaped piece of metal that wraps around the boot ’s heel and is held on by a strap .
#Text=The heel band may have buttons where the straps will attach or bars for threading straps to attach .
#Text=You will need a heel band that is approximately the same size as the heel portion of your cowboy boot .
#Text=Choose 1 long strap if the heel band has bars .
#Text=If the heel band has bars on both sides , you will need 1 long strap with a buckle on one end to attach the heel band to the boot .
#Text=Take a look at your strap to see if it has a decoration , metal work , or fancy design on one side .
#Text=You want the decorative side to always be visible on the outside of your boot .
#Text=Get 2 small straps if the heel band has buttons .
#Text=If the heel band has buttons on both sides , you will need 2 smaller straps with buttonholes .
#Text=These will ultimately buckle together after being attached to both sides of the heel band .
#Text=Take a look at your straps to see if either of them have a decorative , scalloped , or fancy side .
#Text=You want the decorative side to always be visible on the outside of your boot .
#Text=Look for the shank on the spur .
#Text=The shank is a small metal piece that extends from the middle of the heel band .
#Text=The shank should point down once the spur is in place on the boot .
#Text=Spot the rowel on the back of the spur .
#Text=The rowel is the rotating disk with blunt points attached to the shank on the heel band .
#Text=This is the most important part of the spur because it is the part you will use to nudge your horse in the side to communicate your intentions with him .
#Text=Exercise caution when handling the rowel so that you do n’t accidentally cut yourself .
#Text=Most are n’t incredibly sharp but could still cause pain if grabbed too tightly .
#Text=Assembling the Spur
#Text=Gather all the pieces needed to assemble your spur .
#Text=You ’ll need to grab your boots , heel band ( with rowel attached ) , and the straps you will be using .
#Text=This is a perfect time to position any decorative strap sides where you want them before attaching them to the heel band .
#Text=Attach button straps onto heel bands with buttons .
#Text=For this type of heel band , you will need 2 small straps with buttonholes .
#Text=The straps will be attached on either side of the heel band and then buckled across the boot later .
#Text=Hold the heel band in your hand with the shank facing down .
#Text=Start with one side of the heel band and place the first strap with the buttonhole over the heel band button .
#Text=Spread the buttonhole apart to push the button through the hole .
#Text=Rotate the strap around the button until it lays down flat .
#Text=Repeat with the other side of the heel band and attach the second strap .
#Text=Thread straps into a heel band with bars .
#Text=For this type of heel band , you will need 1 longer strap with a buckle .
#Text=With 1 long strap you will thread it through both sides of the heel band and buckle it across the boot later .
#Text=Hold the heel band in your hand with the shank facing down .
#Text=Begin threading the strap from the inside of the outward facing heel band bar .
#Text=Thread the strap through the bars .
#Text=The buckle should end up on the outside of your boot .
#Text=Leave some strap to go under the boot and then thread the same strap into the other side of the heel band through the bars .
#Text=Attaching the Spur to Your Boot
#Text=Fit the heel band to the spur ledge of your boot .
#Text=The heel band should rest on the spur ledge with the shank facing down .
#Text=The fit should not be too tight or too loose .
#Text=There should be a little bit of movement for the spur to fit correctly .
#Text=If the fit is off just slightly , you may be able to gently pull it apart to loosen it or squeeze a bit to tighten it .
#Text=Attach the spur to your boot by buckling the straps .
#Text=Once the heel band is fitted in place at the back of your boot , buckle the strap or straps together over the boot to create a snug fit .
#Text=Put the buckles on the outside of the boots .
#Text=If the buckles are facing the inside of the boots , they will rub together at your ankles and be uncomfortable .
#Text=Adjust the strap so that the spur fits snugly onto the boot .
#Text=If the spur is too tight or too loose once buckled onto your boot , you may need to let some strap in or out of the buckle to adjust the fit .
#Text=Start by unbuckling the strap .
#Text=Next , adjust the length of the strap as needed to ensure a good fit .
#Text=Finish up by re-buckling the strap .
#Text=Tips
#Text=If you are having trouble attaching the spur to your boot while you are wearing the boots , try fitting the spur to the boot and buckling them in place before slipping the boot onto your foot .
